Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] A.C. 562 (.raw_text: Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] A.C. 562 (foundational duty principles)
Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] A.C. 562 (.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to Plaintiff, as an invitee on Defendant’s premises, to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of or make safe dangerous conditions of which Defendant knew or in the exercise of reasonable care should have known.

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (proximate cause principles)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: Occupiers of land owe invitees a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining the premises in a safe condition and to warn of dangerous conditions known to the occupier that are not obvious to the invitee.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: The Palsgraf opinion addresses the relational nature of duty and proximate cause in negligence, not the specific premises-liability duty owed by land occupiers to invitees. Cardozo’s analysis focuses on whether the railroad owed any duty to this particular plaintiff based on foreseeability, not on maintaining premises in a safe condition or warning of non-obvious dangers. The case is thus not authority for the invitee-duty proposition and is being cited for the wrong legal principle.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The conduct of the defendant’s guard, if a wrong in its relation to the holder of the package, was not a wrong in its relation to the plaintiff, standing far away. Relatively to her it was not negligence at all. Nothing in the situation gave notice that the falling package had in it the potency of peril to persons thus removed. Negligence is not actionable unless it involves the invasion of a legally protected interest, the violation of a right.”

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, \u00a7 2A (thre.proposition: Plaintiff timely files this action within the applicable statute of limitations for personal injury actions under Massachusetts law.
